questions.question: A 65-year-old woman presents with fatigue, night sweats and unintentional weight loss over the past few months. Physical examination reveals palpable lymph nodes and enlarged spleen. Lab tests show significant lymphocytosis (>20,000/ µ L) with small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. What is true regarding the origin and risk factors of the patient’s condition?

options.A: B cells, no exposure to radiation

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) B cells, no exposure to radiation Explanation: Based on the above scenario, the patient is most likely suffering from Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. CLL is one of the cancers not associated with radiation exposure and originates from B cells. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia Genetics: Trisomy 12, deletion 13q14 , and others Origin: Post–germinal center memory B cell or naive B Cells in the mantle zone of the lymph node (Option A) Etiopathogenesis Antiapoptotic protein BCL2 overexpression. CLL cell growth depends on Bruton Tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity. No association with radiation exposure (Options A and B) Clinical Presentation Most common leukemia in the elderly. Frequently asymptomatic at diagnosis. May present with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or infection due to immunosuppression. Associated with autoimmune hemolytic anemia- spherocytes can be seen on peripheral smear Can lead to Hypogammaglobulinemia as B cells are abnormal Infection is the M/C/C of death in CLL Laboratory diagnosis: Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) > 5000/mm3 Bone marrow lymphocytes >30% Surface markers using flow cytometry positive for CD5, CD23, CD19, CD20. CLL co-expresses both T cell (CD5) and B cell (CD20, CD19) markers. Myeloid cells and Philadelphia chromosomes are seen in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (Options C and D) . Reference: Robbin’s and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 597

questions.question: A 65-year-old male presents with generalised fatigue and night sweats. Lab tests reveals Hemoglobin (Hb) 12 g/dL Platelet count 150,000/µL Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) 45,000/µL Total leukocyte count (TLC) 70,000/µL Differential leukocyte count (DLC) 70% lymphocytes, 20% neutrophils, 5% monocytes, and 5% eosinophils Based on these lab findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) CLL Explanation: The diagnosis is CLL due to the following laboratory findings: Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) is significantly elevated (45,000/µL), a characteristic finding in CLL. Diagnostic ALC >5000/mm3. Total leukocyte count (TLC) is elevated (70,000/µL), consistent with leukemia. The differential leukocyte count (DLC) shows 70% lymphocytes, further supporting the CLL diagnosis. In CLL, there is a proliferation of mature-appearing lymphocytes. ALL ( Option A): ALL is characterised by the presence of a high blast count in the peripheral blood. The absence of blasts in the differential count and the presence of mature lymphocytes make ALL less likely. AML ( Option B): AML involves the rapid proliferation of myeloid blasts in the bone marrow, often leading to high leukocyte counts. While the leukocyte count is elevated in this case, the differential leukocyte count (DLC) shows mainly lymphocytes, which is not characteristic of AML. CML ( Option C): CML is characterised by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome and the overproduction of mature and immature granulocytes. The absence of basophilia, thrombocytosis, and the predominance of lymphocytes in the differential count make CML less likely. Reference: Robbin’s and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Pages 595-598, 617

questions.question: A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss over the past several months. Examination reveals generalised lymphadenopathy and mild splenomegaly. Peripheral blood smear is shown below. Which of the following is not typically associated with the patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Di Guglielmo Disease Explanation: Based on the clinical presentation, laboratory findings, and HPE image, the patient's diagnosis is Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL). CLL is not associated with Di Guglielmo Disease. Di Guglielmo Disease, or acute erythroid leukemia, represents a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterised by the proliferation of erythroid precursors in the bone marrow. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA) (Option A): AIHA is associated with CLL, sometimes occurring independently or in Evan’s syndrome, along with immune thrombocytopenia. It results from autoantibodies produced by malignant B cells. Peripheral smear may reveal spherocytes (round, hyperchromatic RBCs). Evan’s syndrome (Option B ): Evan’s syndrome is associated with CLL. It is characterised by the simultaneous or sequential presence of AIHA (Coomb’s positive) and immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). questions.question: A 52-year-old male presents with complaints of fatigue, abdominal fullness, and night sweats. His complete blood count shows WBC count of 120,000/ µ L. A peripheral blood smear shows an increased number of granulocytes at different stages of maturation. A bone marrow aspirate is shown below. Which of the following features can be seen in this condition?

options.A: Diffusely effaced lymph node architecture with proliferation centres
options.C: Normal marrow cellularity with increased blast cells
options.D: Hypercellular bone marrow with decreased erythroid precursors

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hypercellular bone marrow with decreased erythroid precursors Explanation: The features described in the scenario are consistent with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). CML typically presents with splenomegaly, high white blood cell counts, and a characteristic peripheral blood smear showing increased granulocytes at different stages of maturation. Bone Marrow aspirate findings of CML: Presence of scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm, called sea-blue histiocytes or pseudo-Gaucher cells. The marrow is markedly hypercellular due to massively increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors (elevated eosinophils and basophils) Increased megakaryocytes, commonly with small, dysplastic forms called dwarf megakaryocytes. Normal or slightly decreased erythroid progenitors (increased myeloid : erythroid ratio). Increased deposition of reticulin fibers. Diffusely effaced lymph node architecture with proliferation centers is seen in CLL (Option A) . Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin’s lymphoma (Option B) . Normal marrow cellularity with increased blast cells is seen in AML (Option C) .

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman presents with fatigue, unintentional weight loss, and occasional night sweats over the past few months. On physical examination, cervical lymphadenopathy is noted. A complete blood count reveals leukocytosis with an absolute lymphocyte count of 10,000/mm3. Which of the following flow cytometry marker profiles is most consistent with this form of leukemia?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) CD5+, CD19+, CD23+, CD10- Explanation: Lab investigations with CBC showing leukocytosis with ALC >=5000/mm3 points towards diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) or Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL). It is characterised by specific cell surface markers detected via flow cytometry. The typical CLL immunophenotype includes CD5+, CD10-, CD19+, CD20+ (with dim expression), and CD23+. While CD5 is associated with T-cells, it's abnormally expressed in CLL. CD19 and CD20 are B-cell markers, with CD20 typically appearing dim in CLL. CD23 is also commonly found on CLL cells. Additionally, a new marker, CD200, is recorded positive in CLL, aiding in its diagnosis. CD20+, CD79a+, CD5+, CD25-: CD79a is more common in B-cell lymphomas, and CD25 can be seen in other diseases like hairy cell leukemia (Option B) . CD3+, CD5+, CD19+, CD20-: CD3 indicates a T-cell lineage, which is not characteristic of CLL (Option C) . CD10+, CD19+, CD22+, CD23-: CD10 and CD22 expression is more typical of precursor B-cell lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma. CD23 negativity is also inconsistent with CLL (Option D) . Reference: Robbin’s and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Pages 597, 604

questions.question: Which of the following are the good prognostic factors of CLL?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Expression of MiR-15/16 Explanation: Good prognostic factors Poor prognostic factors Post GC B cell Expression of MicroRNA15 and 16 (acts as tumor suppressors) (Option D) Deletion of 13q14 Naive B-cell NOTCH 1 mutation (commonly associated with Trisomy 12) (Option A) Deletion of 11q, 17p Richter’s transformation (DLBCL transformation) Expression of ZAP 70 (Option C) Increased CD38 expression High β 2-microglobulin levels Lack of somatic hypermutation High LDH levels Reference: Robbin’s and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 597 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 835 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3128231/

questions.question: A 45-year-old man presents with purulent nasal discharge, headache, sore throat, and nonproductive cough. He has maxillary sinus tenderness, pharyngeal erythema, and tender anterior cervical lymphadenopathy. Laboratory results are as follows: Leukocytes 58,000/mm3 Neutrophils 42% Myelocytes 30% Metamyelocytes 8% Band forms 1% Blast cells 1% Eosinophils 6% Basophils 4% The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase score is low. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and its appropriate management/drug for treatment?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) CML and Imatinib mesylate Explanation: This scenario is suggestive of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) as the patient has a markedly elevated white blood cell (WBC) count, increased myeloid precursor forms, basophilia, and eosinophilia in the peripheral blood smear, and a low LAP score. CML Genetics: Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) Origin: Myeloid lineage Etiopathogenesis: BCR-ABL fusion gene due to t(9;22) causes tyrosine kinase activity much above normal Radiation exposure Clinical features: Occurs in adults. Often presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort. Can progress to a blast crisis with features of acute leukemia. Diagnosis: Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis FISH - presence of BCR ABL fusion gene product. Management: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as Imatinib (Option B) Leukemoid reaction (Option A): LAP score is increased in leukemoid reaction, and basophilia is not seen. It is usually due to underlying infections and treated with antibiotics. ALL and vincristine (Option C): Typically, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, which is more common in young children, is characterised by having over 20% bone marrow lymphoblasts and is treated with chemotherapy. AML and stem cell transplant (Option D): Most patients present with a WBC count of approximately 15,000-20,000/mm³ and a significant increase in blast cells (e.g., >20%), unlike the 1% seen in this patient and treated with stem cell transplant. Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28273028/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6415732/

questions.question: A 55-year-old man who is a known case of chronic phase CML presents with increasing fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. His physical examination reveals splenomegaly. Lab tests show a persistent decline in platelet counts, increased circulating basophils, and a blast count of 12%. What is the most likely explanation for the patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings?

options.C: Entry into the blast crisis phase of CML

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Progression to accelerated phase CML Explanation: This patient's increasing anemia and thrombocytopenia, accompanied by a rise in the number of basophils in the blood and a blast percentage of 12%, is consistent with the accelerated phase of CML. The 3 phases of CML and their characteristics are: 1) Chronic phase: Leukocytosis, < 10% blast cells, basophils <20% and monocytosis < 3% 2) Accelerated phase: 10%-19% blasts, ≥ 20% basophils in the peripheral blood or bone marrow Persistent or increasing WBC (>10 × 10^9/L) and splenomegaly, unresponsive to therapy Persistent thrombocytosis (>1000 × 10^9/L), unresponsive to therapy Persistent thrombocytopenia (<100 × 10^9/L) unrelated to therapy This phase often leads to the terminal blast crisis within 6-12 months 3) Blast Crisis: ≥ 20% blasts in peripheral blood or bone marrow In 50% of patients, the blast crisis occurs abruptly without an accelerated phase Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis occurs to compensate for CML and leads to significant splenomegaly Transformation into AML is more predominant than ALL Reference: Robbin’s and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 623 https://doi.org/10.1182/blood-2016-03-643544 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0006497120301567

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and splenomegaly. Lab tests reveal a markedly elevated WBC count with a left shift and increased myeloid precursor forms on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following statements regarding the leukocyte (neutrophil) alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score in this condition is correct?

options.B: Increased due to excessive myeloid cell production
options.C: Decreased due to cytochemical abnormal WBCs
options.D: LAP score is relevant only in acute leukemia

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Decreased due to cytochemical abnormal WBCs Explanation: The leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) score is typically decreased in CML. This is because the WBCs in CML are abnormal, reducing LAP activity. Alkaline phosphatase activity is found predominantly in mature segmented neutrophils. Conditions with Increased and Decreased LAP Score: Increased LAP score Decreased LAP score Leukemoid reaction Neutrophilia / Sepsis Pregnancy OCP Down’s syndrome Chronic Myeloid leukemia Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531464/

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with fatigue, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. Labs reveal a markedly elevated WBC count with a left shift and increased myeloid precursor forms on peripheral blood smear as shown below. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis?

options.B: Flow Cytometry Analysis of Peripheral Blood

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH) Explanation: The investigation of choice to confirm the diagnosis of Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia is fluorescence in situ hybridisation (FISH), which makes a cytogenetic analysis of the Philadelphia chromosome. The presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from the reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22 [t(9;22)(q34;q11)], or detection of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene on mRNA, confirms the diagnosis of CML. CML Genetics: Philadelphia chromosome (t(9;22)) Origin: Myeloid lineage Etiopathogenesis: BCR-ABL fusion gene causes tyrosine kinase activity over normal Radiation exposure Clinical features: Occurs in adults. Often presents with splenomegaly, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and abdominal discomfort. Can progress to a blast crisis with features of acute leukemia. Diagnosis: Bone marrow aspirate to confirm diagnosis FISH - presence of BCR ABL Fusion gene product. Management: Tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as Imatinib Bone Marrow Aspiration and Biopsy: Showing myeloid cells at different stages of maturation can support the diagnosis, it is not the investigation of choice for confirming

questions.question: A 60-year-old male presents with fatigue and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a markedly elevated WBC count with a left shift and increased myeloid precursor forms on peripheral blood smear. Which of the following features would help differentiate Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia (CML) from a leukemoid reaction?

options.D: Resolution of neutrophilia after treating the underlying cause

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Massive splenomegaly Explanation: Extensive extramedullary hematopoiesis in CML frequently leads to significant splenomegaly, with the spleen often containing infarcts of various ages. In contrast, leukemoid reaction does not cause splenomegaly. Key differences between leukemoid reaction and CML: Characteristics CML Leukemoid Reaction Cause t (9:22) BCR/ABL fusion gene Sepsis Spleen Massive Splenomegaly No splenomegaly TLC High High but not as high as CML LAP score Decreased (Option B) Increased Basophils > 20% in accelerated phase No basophilia Reference: Robbin’s and Cotran Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 623 https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16962944/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531459/
